did.abstract: Irving Moy is the child of two Chinese parents. His experiences growing up in Bridgeport represent an insight into the city's Chinese American community after the Second World War. Present in the collection is documentation of Moy's childhood in Bridgeport, his interest in the American Civil War and the Chinese American soldier, Joseph Pierce, and his career within Connecticut's healthcare and social service systems. Mr. Moy continues to be active and involved with his interests.

bioghist.head: Biography
bioghist.p: Irving Moy was born in 1948, as a part of the post WWII boom. His parents were both Chinese and entered the country illegally due to the Chinese Exclusion Act. Regardless, they were citizens and actively involved in the Bridgeport community. They ran a laundry, and Irving grew up within the Chinese Bridgeport community.

He attended school in Bridgeport for his entire K-12 career and went on to earn an A.B. from Washington University in 1970, a masters degree in architecture from Washington University in 1972, and a masters of arts in guidance and counseling from Fairfield University in 1976.

This wide array of education helped him to have a thirty two year long career in healthcare, where he worked in both the private sector and public sector over the years. His years of dedicated service saw him work with the Connecticut Department of Social Services to help develop requirements in Public Act 05-187, especially as it related to fire safety. Moy also helped draft reports submitted to the federal government containing similar information.

Moy also is president of Company F, 14th Connecticut Volunteer Infantry, which re-enacts the work of the infantry during the American Civil War. Moy's focus is on Joseph Pierce, the highest ranking Chinese soldier who fought in the Civil War. He has published a book regarding Pierce, shedding important light on the presence of non-white citizens who participated in the conflict.
Moy's Civil War interest also saw him serve as a member of the 2009 Connecticut Abraham Lincoln Bicentennial Commission, as appointed by Governor M. Jodie Rell.
Mr. Moy continues to be active and involved with his interests, with the Wallingford Historical Society, and Central High School from which he graduated in Bridgeport, Connecticut.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content of Collection
scopecontent.p: The contents of the Irving Moy papers vary greatly, and reflect a diverse array of interests. In addition to Moy's interest in the American Civil War and his research on Joseph Pierce, there is extensive documentation of his childhood in Bridgeport, Connecticut, as well as information on the Chinese community of Bridgeport during the 1940s through the 1960s. This is reflected in his school material, as well as documents and photographs from the Bridgeport Chinese Community.
Additional material relates to Moy's career in healthcare, friends, and memorabilia collected. More accruals are likely to come into the collection.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: Series I primarily contains material related to Moy's childhood and high school years spent growing up in Bridgeport, Connecticut. These include report cards, student newspapers, and a folder of material from cartoonist Phil Mendez who was a schoolmate. Material from college is also present.

Series II contains both personal material related to Moy's immediate family, including documentation of passage and naturalization, as well as photographs and material related to the larger Chinese community within Bridgeport.
Series III contains material relating to Moy's friends.
Series IV contains material relating to the American Civil War. Most of the material focuses on the Chinese soldier Joseph Pierce, but contains other research as well.
Series V relates to the Connecticut Abraham Lincoln Bicentennial Commission, whereas series VI contains additional outstanding material.
Series VII collects oversize material. Attempts have been made to mirror the above organization, but size has demanded some mixing of material.
